title.rendered: UCU Members Back Strikes Over Pensions, Pay and Conditions

content.rendered:
79% of UCU members voted in favour of strike action in the ballot over changes to the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS). These changes would have led to UCU members being approximately £240,000 worse off due to changes in the pension scheme.

The results of the vote were first reported by the UCU on the 31st of October.  

The UCU of Durham also backed strike action due to pay casualisation, equality and workloads. A recent report by the Universities and Colleges Employers Association UCEA showed that pay for university staff has dropped by around 17% in real terms since 2009.

Last year university campuses including Durham were brought to a standstill over the USS pension scheme.

The UCU general secretary Jo Grady said: “’It is incredibly frustrating that we had to ballot members again, but universities only have themselves to blame after failing to address falling real-terms pay and for refusing to deal with casualisation, workloads and the rising cost of USS pensions.”

The strike action has been received positively by most Student Unions. Shadow education secretary Angela Rayner called on both sides to get around the table for urgent talks and said that she fully supported UCU members fighting for fair pay and decent pensions.

The Durham Student Union President Kate McIntosh stated on twitter, that she was unequivocally in support of the strike but that strike action must be member-led.

The National Union of Students President Zamzam Ibrahim reiterated that support and stated that: “We support and stand with UCU members in this fight and will work with students’ unions to build student support. We know that together students and workers can and will win and we look forward to building a better and more just education system together.”
